Or the ever-growing batch of tech companies that help keep Apple at the top of the global wireless and internet revolution?…

Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) swung to a fourth-quarter profit as copper prices recovered, but earnings fell well short of forecasts, sending shares lower Wednesday after a prior-day surge.The miner earned 25 cents per share, missing estimates of 34 cents, reversing a year-ago loss of 2 cents a share. Revenue jumped 24.5% to $4.377 billion but came in shy of the $4.42 billion consensus.CEO Richard Adkerson painted a positive picture about the outlook in the conference call, expressing confidence in a "bright future for copper" with future "deficits in the marketplace" looking like a sure thing.Yet the near-term picture for the miner is clouded by uncertainty in its Indonesia operations, where "productivity issues" at its Grasberg mine contributed to a shortfall in revenue, Adkerson said. A bigger concern involves uncertainty over the ability to export out of Indonesia under new government regulations.While Adkerson said that the government has indicated exports won't be restrained, license approval hasn't yet been secured. Noting that the company isn't in position to build up inventories in Indonesia, Adkerson said there's potential for a big impact on the company, including layoffs and a cutback in capital spending.Troubles in Indonesia come as everything else seems to be falling into place for Freeport, which has sharply curtailed its debt and stands to benefit from further rises in the price of copper."As we enter 2017, we are enthusiastic about opportunities to generate future values for shareholders through our portfolio of high-quality, long-lived copper resources," Adkerson said in a statement.Freeport shares shot out of a nine-week base on Tuesday, clearing a buy point at 16.03 and closing up 8.3% at 17.02. Shares pulled back below that buy point for a while on Wednesday but ended the regular session down 3.1% to 16.50 on the stock market today.Shares of rival BHP Billiton (BHP) ticked up 0.3% to 41.68 at the close, while Vale (VALE) inched up 2 cents to 10.78 and Rio Tinto (RIO) added 0.6% to 45.96.IBD'S TAKE: Freeport-McMoRan is among the Leaderboard stocks IBD's top market writers track on a daily basis to help readers spot buying opportunities when they emerge and sell signals to lock in profits.Freeport's second breakout since Donald Trump's electoral victory came as the price of copper hit its highest level in more than a year, lifted by hopes for a major infrastructure push in the U.S. as well as potential supply issues.Meanwhile, BHP faces a potential strike at a copper mine that produces 5% of global output. Earlier Wednesday, BHP cut its yearly copper production forecast, helping fuel the rally in prices.RELATED:S&P 500, Nasdaq Hit Highs As Trump-Tied Issues ThriveOption Trading: Freeport, PayPal, Proofpoint Set Up Ahead Of Earnings
Stock futures skidded lower ahead of Tuesday's open, as global currencies, markets and commodities reacted to a policy shift in China.

Dow futures appeared to be feeling for a bottom around 140 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 22.41 points. S&P 500 futures were off a stiff 14.2 points. Small caps looked to be particularly hard hit, with Russell 2000 futures down more than 11 points.

The stock market today sees the Nasdaq and S&P 500 at least briefly back above their 50-day moving averages. Monday's gains were broad, spurred by a Precision Castparts (PCP) acquisition and Federal Reserve assurances that interest rates wouldn't change until inflation hit 2%.

But the advance carried in weak volume, suggesting the enthusiasm didn't run too deep. Traders suspect this may be the case through the rest of the August vacation season, suggesting markets will stick to their tightly bound trading ranges through Labor Day.

U.S. economic news opened with the Labor Department's preliminary estimate on Q2 productivity, up 1.3% and a healthy jump from Q1's 1.1% slip. But the Q2 number was below economist consensus expectations for a 1.6% increase. Unit labor costs rose 0.5%, down from Q1's 6.7% surge and in line with forecasts.
The Commerce Department reports wholesale business inventory data for June at 10 a.m. ET.
The bigger economic news came from China's central bank, which on Tuesday freed the yuan up to 2% with market forces. The move sent the currency down 2% in its biggest one-day adjustment since 1994.

It was the currency's first major downward adjustment since the Chinese government began a decade ago to dismantle its policy of holding the yuan artificially low vs. the dollar, a strategy that gave China exports an advantage on international markets.

The People's Central Bank of China move followed data last weekend showing China's exports slumped unexpectedly in July and the country's producer price index saw its biggest drop in more than five years.

The change was the most recent by a Chinese leadership that has become increasingly erratic in its effort to brake its slowing economy and manage its burgeoning stock markets. Despite the scale of the maneuver, China's markets showed little reaction, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index ending down 0.1% and the Shanghai Composite off a fraction.

Oil prices backed off a bit less than 2%, giving back most of Monday's gains. Copper dumped 3%. Gold rose a fraction. Europe's markets rounded down to notable losses, with Frankfurt's DAX slipping 1.8%, Paris' CAC-40 1.2% lower and the FTSE 100 in London showing a 0.8% decline heading into the lunch hour.
In U.S. premarket trade, mining issues reacted to the currency change, with Freeport McMoRan (FCX), Vale (VALE), BHP Billiton (BHP) and Arcelor Mittal (MT) all sharply lower.
Company news was also moving stocks, with Google (GOOGL) up 6% after announcing late Monday it would restructure, creating a new publicly traded parent company named Alphabet.
Google will operate as a subsidiary under Alphabet. The company also named a new chief executive to Google, Sundar Pichai. Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin will manage Alphabet.

Symantec (SYMC) climbed 2% after agreeing to sell its data management unit Veritas for $8 billion to an investors led by Carlyle Group and including Singapore sovereign-wealth fund GIC. Symantec shares have been struggling against a deepening decline since January.

On the earnings front, Vipshop (VIPS) slumped 6% in premarket action after reporting late Monday its second-quarter earnings and revenue topped expectations, and operating margins expanded by two-thirds over year-ago levels.

But Q3 revenue guidance was on the weak side — at the low end of analyst estimates and slower than second-quarter growth. Vipshop has been fighting to retake its 10-week moving average, in a consolidation that ended Monday's session 32% below its late April high.Stock futures skidded lower ahead of Tuesday's open, as global currencies, markets and commodities reacted to a policy shift in China.Dow futures appeared to be feeling for a bottom around 140 points below fair market value. Copper declined to the lowest since 2009 as manufacturing data added to evidence that demand is slowing in China, the world's biggest consumer of metals. A private gauge of Chinese manufacturing unexpectedly fell to the lowest in 15 months. Investors in the nation who are banned from shorting equities may be selling copper instead, exacerbating the metal's collapse. The rout…

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.
Stocks dropped hard out of the starting gate Tuesday as global currency, commodities and stock markets responded to a sudden shift in China's monetary policy.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 fell hardest, down 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively. The Nasdaq, with lower commodities exposure and buoyed by Google's (GOOGL) early gain, slipped 0.4%.
Volume was up, rising 6% on the Nasdaq and up 14% on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday.

Economic news played a small part in Tuesday's tumble, after the Labor Department reported a lower-than-expected preliminary estimate for Q2 productivity, up 1.3% vs. 1.6% consensus views. But it also sharply revised Q1's decline from 3.1% to 1.1% and pared Q1's leap in unit labor costs to 2.3%, from its prior estimate of 6.7%. Both were positive revisions. Unit labor costs in Q2 rose 0.5%, in line with expectations.
In addition, the Commerce Department said that wholesale inventories expanded 0.9% in June, up from May's downwardly revised 0.6% increase and more than double the 0.4% gain forecast by economists.
The prevailing news on the stock market today was out of China, where a surprise currency policy shift sent the yuan down 2% vs. the dollar and flustered global currency and commodities markets.
In Europe, officials in the eurozone and Greece said that they had agreed to broad terms for a new three-year, $93 billion bailout package and that only final details remained.
Equally important market news came from Google late Monday, when it announced a restructuring that would fold its core business into a subsidiary under a holding company named Alphabet.

Google also named a new chief executive, Sundar Pichai, formerly the company's senior vice president of products. Google founder Larry Page will act as CEO of Alphabet, with co-founder Sergey Brin as president. Tuesday's gain sent Google above 700, leaving it just below its July 24 high.

China's currency move dictated many of the major moves on the top indexes. On the Dow, Apple (AAPL), Caterpillar (CAT) and Chevron (CVX) were down more than 2% apiece. On the Nasdaq 100, VimpleCom (VIP), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Micron Technologies (MU), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Baidu (BIDU) were all more than 3% lower. Freeport McMoRan (FCX) and Alcoa (AA) posted the worst losses on the S&P 500.

Among leaders, Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) foundered 16% at the open, after reporting Q2 earnings well below analyst expectations. Revenue rose a better than expected 209%, but Q3 earnings guidance stopped well short of consensus projections. The tumble killed a base-building effort and sent shares below their 40-week moving average in heavy trade.

Other IBD 50 stocks opening lower included CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Universal Insurance (UVE), down 2% each. None of the early advancers on the list reached 1%.Stocks dropped hard out of the starting gate Tuesday as global currency, commodities and stock markets responded to a sudden shift in China's monetary policy.The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 fell hardest, down 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively. The Nasdaq, with lower commodities exposure and buoyed by Google's (GOOGL) early gain, slipped 0.4%.Volume was up, rising 6% on the Nasdaq and up 14% on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday.Economic news played a small part in Tuesday's tumble, after the Labor Department reported a lower-than-expected preliminary estimate for Q2 productivity, up 1.3% vs. 1.6% consensus views. But it also sharply revised Q1's decline from 3.1% to 1.1% and pared Q1's leap in unit labor costs to 2.3%, from its prior estimate of 6.7%. Both were positive revisions. Unit labor costs in Q2 rose 0.5%, in line with expectations.In addition, the Commerce Department said that wholesale inventories expanded 0.9% in June, up from May's downwardly revised 0.6% increase and more than double the 0.4% gain forecast by economists.The prevailing news on the stock market today was out of China, where a surprise currency policy shift sent the yuan down 2% vs. the dollar and flustered global currency and commodities markets.In Europe, officials in the eurozone and Greece said that they had agreed to broad terms for a new three-year, $93 billion bailout package and that only final details remained.Equally important market news came from Google late Monday, when it announced a restructuring that would fold its core business into a subsidiary under a holding company named Alphabet.Google also named a new chief executive, Sundar Pichai, formerly the company's senior vice president of products. Google founder Larry Page will act as CEO of Alphabet, with co-founder Sergey Brin as president. Tuesday's gain sent Google above 700, leaving it just below its July 24 high.China's currency move dictated many of the major moves on the top indexes. On the Dow, Apple (AAPL), Caterpillar (CAT) and Chevron (CVX) were down more than 2% apiece. On the Nasdaq 100, VimpleCom (VIP), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Micron Technologies (MU), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Baidu (BIDU) were all more than 3% lower. Freeport McMoRan (FCX) and Alcoa (AA) posted the worst losses on the S&P 500.Among leaders, Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) foundered 16% at the open, after reporting Q2 earnings well below analyst expectations. Revenue rose a better than expected 209%, but Q3 earnings guidance stopped well short of consensus projections. The tumble killed a base-building effort and sent shares below their 40-week moving average in heavy trade.Other IBD 50 stocks opening lower included CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Universal Insurance (UVE), down 2% each. None of the early advancers on the list reached 1%.

The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened higher Friday as all three reached new record levels.The Dow industrials and S&P 500 advanced 0.2% while the Nasdaq clung to a  0.1% gain.The Russell 200 climbed 0.3% in solid volume after Thursday's 1.5% pop. The small-cap index is making a pretty good case for support at the 50-day moving average.Inside the Dow, Intel (INTC) eased 1% at the open after Canaccord Genuity downgraded the chipmaking giant's shares to hold from buy. Shares of Intel slumped 2.5% Thursday in heavy volume after the company talked about lower margins in its data center business. Nvidia (NVDA) briefly popped to 120.70, but reversed to trade down more than 2% to 113.72. Nvidia's weekly chart shows a cup-shaped base with a 120.03 buy point. But it's a late-stage base after a huge run.Nvidia reported blowout earnings growth and yet another quarter of accelerating revenue gains, but guidance was only so-so.Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) jumped 4.5% and reclaimed a prior 16.03 buy point. Indonesia granted the copper producer new mining permits. The price of copper was also up nearly 2% in early trading.Jack In The Box (JACK) reclaimed its 50-day moving average Friday as it works on a flat base with a 113.40 buy point. MarketWatch reported that SunTrust Robinson Humphrey upgraded shares to buy and raised its price target to 122 from 102.On the downside, Yelp (YELP) crashed 13%. Earnings and sales topped expectations late Thursday, but its guidance disappointed.In merger and acquisition news, U.K.-based Reckitt Benckiser, whose brands include Lysol and Mucinex cold medicine, announced plans to acquire Mead Johnson Nutrition (MJN) for $16.6 billion. Shares of Mead Johnson soared 21% on Feb. 2 after the company acknowledged talks with Reckitt. Mead Johnson shares were up 5% early Friday.Sears (SHLD) soared 30% at the open after the struggling retailer said it delivered significant improvement in operating performance in the fourth quarter. Sears also announced more plans to streamline operations which the company expects will generate cost reductions of at least $1 billion on an annualized basis.March U.S. crude oil futures rose 1.7% early Friday to $53.88 a barrel, after OPEC said it achieved 90% compliance to recent production curbs. The 10-year Treasury yield was up 2 basis points to around 2.42%.RELATED:Nvidia Earnings, Sales Crush Views As Demand Booms In All Markets, But Guidance Is So-So

The Dow Jones industrial average finally cleared the 20,000 level Wednesday, helped by a breakout in shares of Boeing (BA).The Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite all showed gains of around 0.6% to 0.7%. The Russell 2000 small-cap index added 0.7%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking about 15%-20% higher than Tuesday's levels.Homebuilders and infrastructure stocks outperformed. NVR Inc. (NVR) soared 9% to 1854 as it tries to clear a long consolidation with an 1845.10 buy point. IShares U.S. Home Construction (ITB), a popular homebuilder ETF, added nearly 2% to 29.56. Boeing is at the high end of a buy range from a 160.17 buy point.Cisco Systems (CSCO) added as much as 1.5% after it swooped in and bought highly anticipated IPO AppDynamics for $3.7 billion. Sales of commercial-grade unmanned aerial vehicles, or drones, are set to soar over the next 10 years, driven by applications such as filmmaking, mapping, prospecting and disaster relief.Market research firm Tractica predicts that worldwide shipments of commercial drones will increase from 80,000 units to nearly 2.7 million units in 2025.Tractica sees drone hardware sales rising from $283 million this year to nearly $4 billion in 2025.Services enabled by commercial drones could generate annual revenue of $8.7 billion in 10 years, up from $170 million this year, Tractica said in a report Tuesday."The two primary application categories in the commercial drone sector are aerial imaging and data analysis," Tractica analyst Clint Wheelock said in a statement. "Key industries that will drive the adoption of commercial drones include film, media, agriculture and oil and gas."Meanwhile, the strong growth in the drone-enabled services market will be driven by applications such as filming and entertainment, mapping, aerial assessments, prospecting and disaster relief."Still, the nascent industry faces significant challenges, Wheelock said. They include regulatory policy, public perception, safety and privacy.The Federal Aviation Administration is working on regulations for commercial drone operations in U.S. airspace. Companies hope to use drones for such tasks as inspecting crops and pipelines, news gathering and even package delivery if Amazon.com (AMZN) has its way.Companies that have received special exemptions from the FAA to fly their drones include food-processing and commodities giant Archer Daniels Midland (ADM), infrastructure service firm Aecom Technology (ACM), commercial drone maker AeroVironment (AVAV), mining company Freeport-McMoRan (FCX), engineering services firm Oceaneering International (OII) and GPS company Trimble Navigation (TRMB).

Copper fell to the lowest in six years as a Chinese stock-market rout heightened concern that demand will slow in the Asian nation, the world's biggest metals consumer. Aluminum and lead tumbled into bear markets. Measures by the Chinese government aimed at stabilizing the equities market are failing to stop a sell-off that erased more than $3.2 trillion of value…

Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) slashed its quarterly dividend 84% to 5 cents a share, amid weak commodity prices, driving its shares down Tuesday.The mining company, which is the top U.S. copper producer, with extensive global assets in mineral mining as well as oil and natural gas, said it intends to raise the dividend "as market and business conditions warrant."Freeport management also said in a statement that they plan to make "significant" reductions in capital spending and other costs "and we are evaluating funding opportunities for capital expenditures in our oil and gas business."It was just the latest in a series of cost-cutting moves as a glut of commodities has greatly reduced prices.Last October, Freeport agreed to sell its 80% interest in the Candelaria and Ojos del Salado copper mines in Chile for $1.8 billion cash and contingent payments of up to $200 million.In spring 2014, it sold a stake reportedly worth about $200 million in a New Mexico natural-gas power plant to raise cash. At the time, it also was reportedly looking for a buyer for its Luna Energy Facility, a 600-megawatt natural-gas power plant in Deming, N.M.Shares were down 1% on the stock market today, paring steeper losses earlier in the day.Its stock has skidded 52% from a 39.32 high on July 10, 2014, and it has a near-worst 2 IBD Composite Rating on a scale of 1-99.Freeport is in the Mining-Metal Ores group with Australia-based BHP Billiton (BHP), U.K.-based Rio Tinto (RIO), Brazil's Vale (VALE) and Phoenix-based Southern Copper Co. (SCCO).Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The S&P 500 gave investors little to get excited about during the first quarter as the big-cap benchmark index rose just 0.4%. A look under the hood reveals why. S&P 500 companies were continually ratcheting down their own earnings guidance during the quarter. Energy, materials and the consumer discretionary sectors lowered them the most. Health care and financial sectors raised theirs the most, according to just-released research from FactSet Research Systems.
Stocks in those industries responded as expected.
The market also punished companies with large international exposure as the euro sank, the dollar rose and global economic growth seemed to slow.

Overall, only 16 S&P 500 companies raised Q1 guidance above the FactSet consensus estimate. If no other companies do so, it will be the lowest number since Q1 2006, says FactSet. The number of companies issuing guidance below Wall Street estimates is 85, above the trailing five-year average of 76.

Q1 year-over-year earnings are projected to decline 4.6%. It would be the first decline since Q3 2012, when earnings fell 1%, and the sharpest decline since the financial meltdown, when companies were forecasting a 15.5% earnings decline in Q3 2009.
Companies were forecasting a 4.2% growth rate at the beginning of the quarter.
Energy stocks took a shellacking during Q1. Stocks in the sector issued guidance projecting a 29.8% decline on Jan. 1 but were expecting a 64.1% decline by the end of the quarter.

Twenty-eight of the 43 companies in the sector that issue guidance cut their estimates by 20% or more, led by Marathon Oil (MRO), Murphy Oil (MUR) and Hess (HES). Marathon lowered its guidance from a profit of 11 cents a share to a loss of 39 cents.

The materials sector has an expected earnings decline of 5.7%, compared to a 12.8% gain at the beginning of the quarter. Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) lowered its guidance from 55 cents a share to 2 cents, according to FactSet.

Companies in the consumer discretionary sector cut their Q1 growth projections from 14% to 6%. Mattel (MAT) went from starting the quarter expecting a flat Q1 to projecting an 8-cent-per-share loss. Amazon (AMZN) went from looking for a 15-cent profit to expecting a 13-cent loss.

At a more optimistic corner of the stock market, the health care sector is projecting the best growth rate, 10.5%. Every industry group within the sector reported earnings growth. Biotech was on top with an expected year-over-year gain of 35%; Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Actavis (ACT) expected the best growth. Gilead sees Q1 growth at 52%, and Actavis expects 13%.

Separating companies with significant international exposure, FactSet said that stocks of companies with more than 50% of sales outside the U.S. declined 1.8%, while stocks of companies with 50% of sales inside the U.S. rose 1.5%.The S&P 500 gave investors little to get excited about during the first quarter as the big-cap benchmark index rose just 0.4%. Every industry group within the sector reported earnings growth. Biotech was on top with an expected year-over-year gain of 35%; Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Actavis (ACT) expected the best growth. Gilead sees Q1 growth at 52%, and Actavis expects 13%.Separating companies with significant international exposure, FactSet said that stocks of companies with more than 50% of sales outside the U.S. declined 1.8%, while stocks of companies with 50% of sales inside the U.S. rose 1.5%.
Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) slashed its oil and gas budget following others in the energy industry that have scaled back on operations in recent months.

The mining company also said that its Q4 EPS plunged 70% to 25 cents. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 35 cents. Revenue fell 11% to $5.23 billion, beating views for $4.9 billion. Sales from oil and gas were lower in Q4 as Freeport sold its stake in the Eagle Ford shale formation.
Shares sank 6% to 18.34 on the stock market today. The stock has lost more than half its value since July.

Freeport sees about $6 billion in capital expenditures this year, with $2.3 billion spent on oil and gas projects. That's down from total capex of $7.2 billion last year, with $3.2 billion in oil and gas.

The company also said that it was started looking for "third-party funding for a significant portion of its oil and gas capital expenditures to maintain financial strength and flexibility in response to recent sharp declines in oil prices."
Shale producer Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) also cut its 2015 budget on falling oil prices, lowering its drilling and capital expenditure plan by about 35% vs. 2014 to $450 million-$470 million.

Carrizo plans to keep oil production flat with Q4. "This should maintain our strong balance sheet and also allow us to quickly resume rapid oil production growth once prices recover," said CEO Chip Johnson in the release.

The exploration and production company has been working to lower its service costs as crude prices fall. Carrizo saw a 12% drop in costs at its Eagle Ford operations from late 2014 levels and said that it expects costs to fall 20% by the end of 2015.
Shares fell 3.7%.

Other U.S. shale companies, such as Matador Resources (MTDR), Concho Resources (CXO) and Linn Energy (LINE) have cut their 2015 budgets, and oil majors such as Chevron (CVX) have canceled drilling plans due to lower crude prices. Oil prices have fallen 60% since June.

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.

U.S. stock indexes rose to record highs Tuesday, and strong volume confirmed the move.The Nasdaq rumbled 0.9% higher, as it struck a new intraday high. The S&P 500 climbed 0.7%, also setting an all-time best. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6%. The small cap Russell 2000 leapt 1.6%. Volume in the stock market today rose on both major exchanges.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, the day's top performers included specialty steel and metal ores. Some Trump-tied plays were also showing strength: cement, heavy construction and banks.President Trump continued to wield his pen with executive orders. Trump signed orders to revive the Dakota Access and Keystone XL oil pipelines. He also signed an order to speed up environmental reviews that slow infrastructure projects.Oil stocks reacted with solid gains. Cabot Oil & Gas (COG) retook its 50-day moving average as it rose 3.5%. Volume, though, was light.Blue chips were mostly up. In the 30-stock Dow, DuPont (DD) climbed 4.5% and IBM (IBM), Caterpillar (CAT) and American Express (AXP) followed with gains of nearly 3% and 2%, respectively. On the downside, Verizon Communications (VZ) dropped 4.4%.IBD'S TAKE: Slacker stocks seldom win, but oddly some folks buy into the "it's due" mentality.The S&P 500 harbored a variety of winners. Miner Freeport McMoRan (FCX) surged 8.3%, as it broke out of a cup-with-handle base in strong volume. Heavy construction firm Quanta Services (PWR) broke out of a flat base in fast trade. Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) popped up from the bottom of a consolidation with a 6.7% gain in heavy volume. Lennar (LEN), another homebuilder, echoed Horton's move with a 6% gain in hurried turnover.In the Nasdaq 100, chip stocks were stirring. Chipmaker Micron Technology (MU) advanced 4.4%. Data Storage firm Seagate Technology (STX) added 2.9%. Chip designer Marvell Technology (MRVL) rose 4% as it continued to move within a flat base.In the IBD 50, a list comprised of the best stocks via fundamentals and technicals, winners led losers by an 11-to-1 ratio. The biggest percentage gainer was cement and wallboard provider Eagle Materials (EXP). The midcap stock broke out of a flat base in emphatic volume.Among world stocks, Ireland-based Ingersoll-Rand (IR) broke out of a flat base in above-average volume.RELATED:Hawaiian Air, Steel Dynamics, Texas Instruments Report After CloseAlibaba Crushes Estimates, Raises GuidanceWhich Top-Flight Stocks Are Breaking Out: See The Current List At IBD LeaderboardHow To Invest: Can Trump Revive Reagan's Stock-Market Magic?How To Invest: The Case For A Trump-Era Secular Bull Run In Stocks

The stock market pushed to all-time highs at the close Tuesday in a broad-based rally capped off with a leading 1.7% rise in the Russell 2000.The Nasdaq rallied 0.9%, reaching a new all-time high, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average both followed up with 0.6% gains, moving the blue-chip index within striking distance of 20,000.Volume was tracking much higher across both the NYSE and Nasdaq, according to preliminary figures.DuPont (DD) led the industrials higher after reporting an earnings beat on Monday after the market close. Despite missing on revenue estimates, the stock gained 4.5%, reaching a new 52-week high.On the downside, Verizon Communications (VZ) dropped over 4% following its quarterly earnings release.Alibaba (BABA) gained 3% after being up as much as 5% in the premarket hours. The Chinese e-commerce giant reported blowout earnings and sales earlier this morning. The stock is building the right side of a base.Miners and construction stocks were acting particularly well in the stock market today.Freeport-McMoRan (FCX), a Leaderboard member, soared over 8%, gapping above a 16.04 cup-with-handle buy point seen on the daily chart. The copper mining company reports its quarterly earnings on Wednesday, before the market open.MasTec (MTZ) surged nearly 11% and reclaimed its 50-day line, where it had been fighting for support for the last several weeks. The stock is now about 1% away from a short cup-shaped base's entry at 41.Meanwhile, the lagging sector was medical.Merck (MRK), Pfizer (PFE), and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), all fell 1% to 2%.Johnson & Johnson provided a cautious outlook for 2017 with earnings and revenues that fell short of the Street's estimates.Leading growth stocks in the IBD 50 were very positive at the close with only four stocks in the red.Broadcom (AVGO) continued its recent dominance and was one of the leading stocks within the IBD 50, tacking on 3.5% to its recent gains. The stock is now extended above a 179.52 flat base entry.On the downside, HealthEquity (HQY) was volatile but closed with a minor change. The leading health savings account provider is now at the top of its buy range. The stock broke out of a flat base with a 45.10 entry on surging volume. The stock was initiated with an overweight rating by Keybanc on Monday after the close.Hawaiian Holdings (HA) and Steel Dynamics (STLD), among others, reported their quarterly results after the close.Hawaiian Holdings, the parent of Hawaiian Airlines, met its quarterly earnings estimate, which was for Q4 EPS of $1.28, and surpassed revenue estimates. Shares fell almost 2% after hours.Steel Dynamics, the steel producer, had not announced. It is estimated to report Q4 EPS of 43 cents.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) topped Q4 earnings and sales estimates. Shares rose 1.5%. Texas Instruments (TXN) beat expectations on both top- and bottom-line estimates. Shares edged about 1% lower.Seagate's (STX) quarterly earnings exceeded the Street's views on its earnings and sales figures. Ore miners posted the most powerful gain among industries in the past week, and the third-strongest industry gain over the past four weeks. Copper, iron ore and other metals and raw materials received boosts this week from positive economic data out of China. However, the price of coking coal, meanwhile, has dropped nearly 40% since early December and included a…
Freeport McMoRan (FCX) and other mining-company stocks plunged on further weakness in copper prices, digging the metals sector deeper into a hole Wednesday.
Copper prices dropped 5% for the day after the World Bank revised its global growth outlook downward. Copper fell to $5,571.50 a ton, its lowest point in five and a half years, Reuters said.
Weaker growth in China, the world's second-largest economy, is impacting sales of copper, which is used in housing, electronics, autos and other industries.
The Mining-Metal Ores group is ranked a near-worst 190 on IBD's list of 197 industries.
Shares of diversified copper-gold-silver miner Freeport McMoRan plunged early and were down 12.2% in afternoon trading on the stock market today.
The Phoenix, Ariz.-based mining stock hasn't offered a buy point recently, as it dropped 53% from a July 9 high and is trading well below its 50-day and 200-day averages.

BHP Billiton (BHP), the largest company by market capitalization in the mining group, fell 4.5% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Like Freeport, it's fallen steadily since midsummer and was trading at the lowest point since March 2009.

In August, BHP said that it would separate into two companies, a simplified company with iron ore, copper, coal, petroleum and potash, and a new company that would would have aluminum, nickel, coal, silver and manganese assets. A shareholder vote is slated for May on the demerger proposal.

Glencore, one of the largest copper miners, has the largest exposure on copper. Last summer, Glencore approached Australia's Rio Tinto (RIO) about a possible merger. It was rebuffed, and analysts said that the plunge in copper's price probably rules out any new talks between them, at least for now. Glencore, which trades on the London exchange and over the counter in the U.S. as GLNCY, fell 4%. Rio Tinto slid 2.7%.
Southern Copper (SCCO), another Phoenix-based miner that operates mining, smelting and refining facilities in Peru and Mexico, dipped 5%.
Anglo American, a London-based company trading over the counter in the U.S. as AAUKY, is the world's largest platinum producer and also mines copper and other metals. Anglo American was down 7.5%.
Global X Copper Miners (COPX), an exchange traded fund, also plumbed new lows. Global X gapped down 8.5% to 6.15. As recently as July 29, it was 82% higher at 11.21.

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.
Alcoa said that it will buy German titanium and aluminum aerospace components maker Tital. The acquisition will expand Alcoa's footprint in the sector amid rising demand.
The purchase comes as aerospace giant Boeing (BA) and others expand production. On its second-quarter earnings call, Alcoa (AA) projected that 2014 global aerospace sales will grow 8% to 9%.
Neither side disclosed the Tital purchase's financial terms, but Alcoa says that the boards of both companies have approved the deal, and it expects the deal to close in the first quarter of 2015.
"This acquisition is the next step in building a powerful aerospace growth engine," said Alcoa CEO Klaus Kleinfeld.

Tital is a leader in titanium and aluminum structural castings for aircraft engines and airframes. Alcoa says that it expects Tital's revenue from titanium products to increase by 70% over the next five years as makers of next-generation jet engines look to the tough metal, which can withstand extremely high heat and pressure.

Alcoa may also get a lift from Ford's (F) move to an all-aluminum body on the 2015 model of its F-150 pickup. Ford's F series has been the top-selling truck model in the U.S. for several years running.
Using aluminum cuts about 700 pounds from the F-150's total weight, boosting gas mileage. Other vehicle makers are expected to follow suit.

Alcoa shares rose 1.3% in afternoon trading in the stock market today (Monday). Alcoa's stock has fallen recently as oil prices plumbed new multiyear bottoms. With oil prices down, purchases of gear for oil rigs could slump, too.
Other large companies in the Mining-Metal Ores group didn't get a lift from the announcement.
Australia's BHP Billiton (BHP) was down 2%, Brazil's Vale (VALE) 3.5%, U.K.-based Rio Tinto (RIO) 1.85% and Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) 1.7%.
The metals sectors fell in 2014 amid a glut of supply and slowing demand. The combined stock prices of the 49 companies in the sector fell 36% in 2014 as of Monday morning.

Alcoa formed a cup-with-handle base from Sept. 5 to Oct. 3, when it cleared a 17.03 buy point. But it failed to follow through, rising to an intraday high of 17.75 on Nov. 21, then turned down. Prior to Monday, its stock had closed lower in six straight sessions.

Alcoa (AA) is poised to report fiscal third-quarter earnings results Wednesday amid an expansion drive to make next-generation jetliners.Like other mining and metals companies, Alcoa has been hurt by a multiyear slump in prices amid a glut of metals.The company hopes that use of lighter weight aluminum composite materials in jetliners and cars will lift prices. But slowing economic growth in China, the world's biggest consumer market, is a concern.Consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for New York-based Alcoa to report a doubling of earnings to 22 cents per share vs. the same period a year ago, on a 1.2% hike in revenue to $5.84 billion.The bar is set high. Despite industry doldrums, Alcoa has topped Wall Street estimates in six of the last eight quarters and beaten them the last two periods in a row.On Oct. 2, Alcoa announced the opening of the world's largest manufacturing plant for lightweight aluminum-lithium in Lafayette, Ind. The company said at the time that it wants to be the industry leader in this segment."The future of aviation is being built with aluminum-lithium, and Alcoa is making big moves to capture that demand," CEO Klaus Kleinfeld said in a statement.Alcoa already has contracts for $100 million in aluminum-lithium for jetliners lined up for 2017. Customers include European aerospace consortium EADS (EADSY), which makes the Airbus A380 wide-body jetliner, and Boeing (BA) for its technologically advanced 787 Dreamliner.Alcoa also sells to automakers as they move to the lighter material to meet tougher federal gas mileage standards.Ford Motor (F)was expected to begin shipping a mostly aluminum body and cab version of its F-150 pickup, the best-selling vehicle in the U.S., this quarter. It's 700 pounds lighter and gets up to 20% higher mileage than a standard version.Ford has also unveiled an aluminum version of its flagship Fusion sedan.General Motors (GM) and Chrysler are also working on aluminum body versions of some vehicles.Alcoa shares were up 1.6% in Monday morning trading on the stock market today.Among other large mining and metal processing companies, coal and iron miner BHP Billiton (BHP) rose fractionally, U.K.-based global miner Rio Tinto (RIO) jumped 2% and Brazil's Vale (VALE) nearly 3%. Phoenix, Ariz.-based copper and gold miner Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) was down less than 1%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
