At the moment we are not planning on parting with AXYS, which is still in positive territory overall in the Focus List.

Techne Corporation (TECH  -  Free Report) was added to the Focus List on Dec 10, at the close of trading. TECH provides both biotechnology products, such as cytokines and enzymes, and hematology controls and calibrators. This company provides growth (revenues and earnings have risen for several years) with a lower level of economic risk - a combination we are willing to pay a little more in valuation for. Furthermore, earnings estimates have been revised upward over the past 2 months.
The Growth and Income portfolio outpaced the broader market with a gain of 2.21% on the day.

Flowers Food Inc. (FLO  -  Free Report) was added to the Growth & Income portfolio on Dec 10, at the close of trading. FLO produces fresh and frozen bakery products. The company reiterated its full-year profit guidance last week. Furthermore, estimates for 2009 have been holding steady. (Projections call for 12% profit growth next year.) Finally, FLO yields a dividend of 2.5%.
Headquartered in Phoenix, Arizona Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, Inc., (FCX  -  Free Report), is engaged in
mineral exploration and development; mining and milling of copper, gold, and silver in Indonesia; and
smelting and refining of copper concentrates in Spain and Indonesia.
The company generates about 66%
of its revenue from mining and exploration activities, while the remaining 34% comes from smelting and
refining.
Recently, the company acquired Phelps Dodge
Corporation (PD). The Grasberg mine, the worlds largest copper and gold mine in terms of reserves, will
be joined by Phelps Dodges 14 existing mines and those under development in North and South
America and Africa. The merger would significantly increase diversification and reduce the one-mine,
geo-political risk previously associated with Freeport's Grasberg mine located in Papua, Indonesia. The
combined companys revenue distribution will be as follows: 47% in North America, 35% in Indonesia,
and the remainder in South America.
The company is also developing one of the worlds largest
copper/cobalt project, the Tenke Fungurume mine, in the Democratic Republic of Congo (South Africa).
The company
is witnessing strong growth backed by improved
productivity and a strong cash flow position. The
merger with Phelps Dodge Corporation has
positioned the company as the second largest
copper producer and the largest publicly traded
copper company globally.

FCX released second-quarter financial results in late July, stating that its performance reflects strong results in its North American, South American and Indonesian operations, and a continuation of positive market conditions for copper, gold and molybdenum. The company added that its outlook for its business is strong and it anticipates continuing to generate strong cash flows, which will be used to enhance shareholder value through investments in attractive growth projects, debt reduction and cash returns to shareholders.

Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Golds quarterly earnings improved on a year-over-year basis, and Wall Street is optimistic about its future prospects. Analysts earnings estimates for the full-year 2007 currently stand at $9.48 per share, up from last weeks forecasts of $9.26. The consensus estimate was $9.18 per share one month ago.

Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, Inc. (FCX  -  Free Report) recently reported strong second-quarter and year-to-date results, fueled by its acquisition of rival Phelps Dodge in March and increased metal pricing. Analysts responded by upping their profit forecasts for both this year and next. On Jun 28, FCX announced a quarterly cash dividend to 31.25 cents per share. This Zacks #1 Rank stock has a current dividend yield of 1.38%.
Full Analysis

Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, Inc., through its subsidiaries, engages in the exploration, mining and production of copper, gold and silver. The company sells its concentrates containing copper, gold and silver primarily to companies in Asia and Europe, and to international trading companies.

On Jul 25, FCX reported second-quarter profits of $2.85 per share, which topped the consensus estimate of $2.69 by 6.0%. Compared to earnings of $1.74 per share in the second quarter of 2006, the result equated to an impressive 63.8% year-over-year improvement. Revenues soared to $5.81 billion, versus $1.43 billion in the prior-year period.

The solid numbers were primarily due to the acquisition of rival Phelps Dodge in March, along with increased metal pricing. Prior to this acquisition, FCXs biggest asset was its Grasberg copper facility located in Indonesia. FCX now operates Phelps' former copper and molybdenum mines in the United States and Africa which yielded one billion pounds of copper, 913,000 ounces of gold and 15 million pounds of molybdenum in the quarter.
FCX increased revenues for the past five years, expanded gross margins for the past two years and grew profits for six years running.

Looking ahead, Chairman James R. Moffett and CEO Richard C. Adkerson stated, "The outlook for our business is strong and we anticipate continuing to generate strong cash flows which will be used to enhance shareholder value through investments in attractive growth projects, debt reduction and cash returns to shareholders."

The consensus earnings estimate for this year has risen 86 cents to $9.26 over the past 30 days. Eight of the 12 covering analysts submitted upward revisions. Profit forecasts for next year are up by an even larger margin$1.46 to $10.22 over the same period of time. Upward revisions were submitted by 13 of the 17 covering analysts.

On Jun 28, FCX announced a quarterly cash dividend to 31.25 cents per share. FCX has a current dividend yield of 1.38%. The company is forecasting higher cash flows for the year, which should bode well for the continuation of its dividend distributions. Based on certain pricing assumptions, cash flows are likely to surpass $6 billion for the year.

Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, Inc., through its subsidiaries, engages in the exploration, mining and production of copper, gold and silver. FCX sells its concentrates containing copper, gold and silver primarily to companies in Asia and Europe, and to international trading companies.

On Jul 25, FCX reported second-quarter profits of $2.85 per share, which topped the consensus estimate of $2.69 by 6.0%. Compared to earnings of $1.74 per share in the second quarter of 2006, the result equated to an impressive 63.8% year-over-year improvement. Revenues soared to $5.81 billion, versus $1.43 billion in the prior-year period. The solid numbers were primarily due to the acquisition of rival Phelps Dodge in March along with increased metal pricing.

Looking ahead, Chairman James R. Moffett and CEO Richard C. Adkerson stated, "The outlook for our business is strong and we anticipate continuing to generate strong cash flows which will be used to enhance shareholder value through investments in attractive growth projects, debt reduction and cash returns to shareholders."

The consensus earnings estimate for this year has risen 68 cents to $9.00 over the past 30 days. Eight of the 14 covering analysts submitted upward revisions. Profit forecasts for next year are up by an even larger margin$1.22 to $9.89 over the same period of time. Nine of the 16 covering analysts upped their projections. Earnings per share are projected to grow 31% over the next 3-5 years, with the industry expected to grow at only a 13% clip.

FCX is currently trading at a valuation of 10.0x current fiscal-year estimated earnings and at 9.1x next fiscal-year estimated earnings. The market, as represented by the S&P 500, is trading at a valuation of 15.5x current fiscal-year estimated earnings and at 14.5x next fiscal-year estimated earnings. The company has a price-to-book ratio of 2.7, compared to 4.6 for the market and 4.2 for the industry.

It is going to be an exciting week. The Tour de France could have its general classification shaken up with a brutal mountain stage on Monday. Barry Bonds could break Hank Aarons home run record; he is two shy after hitting two homers at Wrigley on Thursday afternoon. Fans across the world will know how the final confrontation between Harry Potter and Voldemart (sorry, I forgot that I wasnt supposed to say his name) turns out. (And no, I dont know the answer and I dont want anyone spoiling it for me either.)

The economic calendar will have its first report of note on Wednesday with June existing home sales data. Thursday features June new home sales and June durable goods orders. The week ends with the final University of Michigan consumer confidence index and the advance estimate of second-quarter GDP.

Second-quarter earnings will be front and center. We have confirmed scheduled reports for 847 companies, 175 of which are in the S&P 500. Dow components 3M (MMM  -  Free Report), American Express (AXP  -  Free Report), AT&T ( T), Boeing (BA  -  Free Report), Du Pont (DD), ExxonMobil (XOM  -  Free Report) and Merck  (MRK  -  Free Report) will report. Given the possibility of positive surprises (second-quarter estimates for MMM, BA and XOM have been revised higher within the past 30 days), a further ascent by the Dow into record territory seems likely.

Speaking of surprises, results for the second-quarter are looking alright so far. Not great, but certainly nothing to complain about either. Approximately one-fourth of S&P 500 companies have reported and positive surprises are outnumbering negative surprises by a margin of 2.8:1. Median company growth is running at 9.4%. For the broader S&P 1500 (S&P 500, S&P MidCap 400 and S&P SmallCap 600), growth is a little slower at 8.6%. Positive surprises are outnumbering negative surprises by a 2.6:1 ratio. Relative to the same point during first-quarter earnings, median company growth is better this earnings season, but the proportion of negative surprises is also higher. Nonetheless, it is still relatively early, so we caution about reading too much into these numbers.
Companies That Could Issue Positive Earnings Surprises during the Week of July 23  27

One of the things I focused on in last Wednesdays Industry Rank Analysis was an improvement in earnings projections for multiple oil-related companies. Higher oil prices are causing brokerage analysts to change their earnings assumptions. As a result, both ConocoPhillips (COP  -  Free Report) and ExxonMobil (XOM  -  Free Report) could both top expectations when they report second-quarter results.

COP said in early July that worldwide refining margins for the second quarter are expected to be significantly higher than the first quarter. Offsetting this may be a decline in production levels because of maintenance, the companys exit from Dubai and a few other factors. Nonetheless, brokerage analysts believe profits will be above first-quarter and year ago levels. The company is projected to report profits of $2.59 per share, 21 cents more than the consensus estimate of a month ago. The Most Recent Consensus is even more bullish at $2.65 per share. COPs first-quarter results were below expectations, but the company did top estimates during the previous three quarters. ConocoPhillips is scheduled to report on Wednesday, Jul 25, before the start of trading.

XOMs market cap was $521 billion on Friday morning, a sign that investors are reacting positively to raised earnings expectations. (To put this number in perspective, ExxonMobil is currently worth nearly 25% more than General Electric (GE  -  Free Report)). More than half of the covering brokerage analysts have raised their second-quarter forecasts on the oil conglomerate during the past 30 days, sending the consensus estimate 17 cents higher to $1.92 per share. The Most Recent Consensus Estimate is more bullish at $1.95 per share. XOM has exceeded expectations during the each of the past four quarters by an average margin of 15 cents per share. ExxonMobil is scheduled to report on Thursday, Jul 26, before the start of trading.

Volatile copper prices have not deterred brokerage analysts from being optimistic about Freeport-McMoRans (FCX  -  Free Report) second-quarter results. One brokerage analyst raised his forecast over the past week and five others have adjusted their projections during the past 30 days. The net result of these revisions has been a 17-cent increase in the consensus estimate to $2.64 per share. The Most Recent Consensus calls for profits of $2.69 per share. FCX has topped expectations for nine consecutive quarters. Freeport-McMoRan is scheduled to report on Wednesday, Jul 25, before the start of trading.

Despite some bad press, JetBlue (JBLU  -  Free Report) realized a 1.7-point improvement in its load factor during June. (Load factor is the ratio of passenger miles to available seat miles. The more crowded a plane is, the higher load factor is.) This improvement led six of the 11 covering brokerage analysts to raise their forecasts for second-quarter profits. The consensus estimate calls for the discount airline to have earned 11 cents per share, a penny higher than the average forecast of a month ago. The Most Recent Consensus is predicting profits of 12 cents per share. JBLU topped first-quarter estimates by seven cents per share, but missed fourth-quarter expectations by a penny per share. JetBlue is scheduled to report on Tuesday, July 24, before the start of trading.

Companies That Could Issue Negative Earnings Surprises during the Week of Jul 23  27Lexmark International (LXK) recently cut its guidance. Citing a decline in inkjet revenues and aggressive pricing and promotion on hardware, the company expects that adjusted earnings to be in a range of 62 to 67 cents per share, including a tax benefit of five cents per share. The company had previously predicted that second-quarter profits would be in the range of 82 to 92 cents per share. Nearly all of the covering brokerage analysts slashed their forecasts in response, sending the consensus estimate down to 64 cents per share. LXKs first-quarter results were seven cents below expectations. Lexmark is scheduled to report on Tuesday, Jul 24, before the start of trading.

James M. Iocca (aka: watchlist james) is a studious investor. His investment style was developed through diligent research. Departing somewhat from the momentum type of approach many of the other Simulator top players employ, James relies more on the fundamentals in picking his stocks.

This astute investor pays attention to analysts recommendations, and he looks for positive cash flow, solid returns on invested capital and strong balance sheets among other fundamental indicators. While income statements and balance sheets are a big part of his trading game plan, James will also consider important technical attributes, such as stock performance history, current share price trends and the overall market climate.
His research tools include Zacks screening strategies, various analyst reports and well-known publications such as the Wall Street Journal and Barrons.

This contestants investment strategy enabled him to currently hold 15th place in the Zacks $100K Challenge with an overall return of roughly 53% since the beginning of this year. Some of his current portfolio positions include Holly Corp. (HOC), Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc. (FCX  -  Free Report), CROCS Inc. (CROX  -  Free Report), AK Steel Holding Corp. (AKS  -  Free Report) and Massey Energy Co. (MEE) just to name a few. Take a look at this challengers entire portfolio by clicking here. Check out his complete trading history by clicking here.How does he do it?

This market enthusiast, who has achieved a BS, MBA and is currently working a doctoral dissertation in Business Administration, considers several variables before putting in a buy order. For the most part, he screens through the eyes of a fundamentalist. However, like any successful investor, James checks various technical components as well.

He stated that he looks at price/earnings ratios, analysts recommendations, articles relating to the stocks performance in Barrons, Wall Street Journal, Standard and Poor, Dunn & Bradstreet, Business Week, Forbes and Fortune. James added that he also analyzes a stocks performance chart.How does he know when to sell?
A mix of fundamental and some technical analysis is also implemented before this market player gets rid of a position.

When I purchase a stock, I set a percentage loss of 5% to trigger a sale. I also scan to check to see if there is an analyst downgrade or if reported quarterly earnings do not meet analysts expectations, replied James. Moreover, if trading value is declining and the stock price is dropping, this could be a sign that the stock should be sold.Where does he see the market at year-end?

This market watcher said, my stock market outlook is positive because of current and projected economic trends. My prediction as to where the Dow Jones Industrial average will be at the end of 2007 is 14,324.69.Any advice for beginners?

James advocates avid reading. He suggests investors get their hands on as much business news as possible. In addition, this successful investor is a fan of face-to-face consultations with financial advisors. Such interactions will allow individuals to ask questions and learn how to properly place trades. Two things that James believes are important primers before one delves into the market.

The reaction to Alcoas (AA) first-quarter surprise has been positive overall. Since the company reported quarterly profits of 79 cents per share, five of the 15 covering brokerage analysts have raised their full-year forecasts. The new consensus estimate calls for earnings of $3.26 per share, five cents above the average projection of a week ago. It should be noted that one analyst did lower his forecast, but he still remains comparatively bullish with a prediction of $3.30 per share.

Alcoa generated an 11% increase in sales, thanks to both good demand and higher prices. The company saw particular strength in the aerospace market, but also noted that Chinese demand remains very good. CEO Alain Belda described the world market as being robust.

Steel Dynamics (STLD  -  Free Report) followed Alcoas report with its own first-quarter surprise. STLD generated earnings of $1.01 per share, three cents above the upper end of its raised guidance and five cents above the consensus estimate. Revenues rose 30%, reflecting strength in the non-residential construction and industrial markets.

A decline in prices adversely impacted margins; the company saw its average consolidated selling price drop by $31 per ton on a sequential quarterly basis. The price decline may have been caused by higher inventory levels within the channel during the first-quarter  a headwind that raised concern for the entire industry. STLD observed in late-March that inventory levels at steel service centers had declined, however  a bullish sign.

Two of the nine covering brokerage analysts raised their full-year forecasts on STLD following the release of the first-quarter results. The new consensus estimate calls for 2007 earnings to total $3.87 per share versus $3.84 a week ago and $3.76 two months ago.

AA is a Zacks #2 Rank (buy) stock and is classified in Mining-Non Ferrous. This group also contains four Zacks #1 Rank (strong buy) stocks: Chalco (ACH), Anglo American (AGPPY), Freeport McMoRan (FCX  -  Free Report) and Kaiser Aluminum (KALU  -  Free Report). STLD is a Zacks #3 Rank (hold) stock and is classified in Steel-Producers. This group contains five Zacks #1 Rank stocks, AK Steel Holdings (AKS  -  Free Report), Arcelor Mittal (MT  -  Free Report), CIA Siderur (SID  -  Free Report), Schnitzer Steel (SCHN  -  Free Report) and U.S. Steel (X  -  Free Report).

Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, Inc. (FCX  -  Free Report), which was first presented on May 17, topped the Streets earnings estimate for the past eight quarters by an average margin of 16.2%. Consensus estimates have been trending higher. Earnings per share are forecasted to grow 35% over the next 3-5 years. FCX has a current dividend yield of 2.2% and a five-year average dividend yield of 1.5%.
Full Analysis

Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, Inc. engages in the exploration, mining and production of copper, gold and silver. The company's operations are conducted through its subsidiaries, PT Freeport Indonesia, PT Irja Eastern Minerals and Atlantic Copper, S.A.

When FCX was first featured as a Growth and Income stock on May 17, it had exceeded analysts earnings estimates for six consecutive quarters. Over the past two quarters, the company surprised to the upside yet again. For the past eight quarters, FCXs average margin of surprise was 16.2%.

On Oct 17, the company posted third-quarter profits of $1.58 per share. With analysts calling for $1.50, the company beat estimates by 5.3%. Compared to the prior-year period, earnings soared 83.7%. Revenues jumped 66.8% to $1.64 billion from $983.3 million a year ago.
For the first nine months of the year, profits ballooned 105.7% and revenues rose 51.9%. FCX increased revenues for the past four years and grew profits for five years running.

Consensus estimates for this quarter and next quarter are up 11.0% and 32.4%, respectively, over the past 90 days. Profit forecasts for the full years of 2006 and 2007 jumped 3.2% and 13.1%, respectively, over the same period of time. Earnings per share are forecasted to grow 35% over the next 3-5 years, which crushes the 15% projected growth rate of the industry.

The Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of 31.25 cents per common share of stock on Oct 4. Furthermore, on Aug 1, the Board announced a supplemental common stock dividend of 75 cents per share. The supplemental dividend was paid in addition to the companys regular quarterly dividend. FCX has a current dividend yield of 2.2% and a five-year average dividend yield of 1.5%.

FCX is a Zacks #2 Rank (Buy) stock. Zacks #2 Rank stocks have generated an average annual return of 21.6% since 1988. Because the Zacks Rank has a market cap bias, Growth & Income investors may find a greater number of large-cap stocks by considering both Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) and Zacks #2 Rank (Buy) stocks in their selection criteria.

We are coming to the end of the second quarter and in just a few short weeks we will be in the heart of earnings season. We have been starting to get a few early reports in (we define the second quarter as the fiscal period ending in May June or July) and the results have been extremely positive so far. Granted these firms are not a representative sample, but so far so good. The most noteworthy of the early reporters are four big investment banks, which blew earnings expectations out of the water.

However, as we enter the quarter, analysts are a bit on the cautious side with the median year-over-year growth rate expected in the S&P 500 at only 8.3%. That is a sharp slowdown from the 13.2% growth posted in the first quarter. Yet shortly before the first quarter reporting season started the analysts were only expecting 8.9% growth for that quarter. Positive surprises then simply overwhelmed disappointments by better than 3:1 and the actual growth was much higher than expected. It would not shock me at all to see that happen again in the second quarter. The three sectors with the highest expected growth for the quarter are Energy (38.3%), Industrials (16.0%) and Materials (14.3%). All three sectors are also continuing to see strong upward estimate revisions for both this year and next.

For all of 2006, earnings growth is expected to be very solid. The median expected growth rate among S&P 500 firms is 11.4%, and the strength is expected to continue into next year with 12.9% growth expected. The picture is fairly similar if growth is measured on a total net income basis as well. For 2006, total earnings of S&P 500 firms are expected to expand by 13.6% and continue with 10.9% growth in 2007. There is no evidence that this growth is about to falter. If it were to start to do so, it would first show up in the estimate revisions data. As things stand now, analysts are on balance still raising more estimates than they are cutting. Over the last month, a total of 566 estimates for 2006 were raised while only 488 were cut (ratio of 1.16). For next year there were 508 increases versus 386 cuts (ratio of 1.32). The absolute number of estimate revisions is at a seasonal low point, as earnings season gets underway expect to see the number close to triple. However, the ratio of increases to cuts is still significant.
Among the most significant upward revisions in 2006 estimates this week were:

Phelps Dodge (PD) - While copper prices are off their highs, they are still way up from a year ago. In the last week, PDs mean estimate for 2006 is up 1.25%, and is up 3.84% over the last month. For 2007, the mean estimate is up 2.84% over the last month. For both years, the last month has seen three analysts raise their estimates with none cutting. (The revisions were made to pre-merger forecasts.) Other copper firms such as Freeport-McMoran (FCX  -  Free Report) and Southern Copper (PCU) have also been seeing upward earnings revisions.Bear Sterns (BSC)  Like the other big investment banks, Bear Sterns reported better than expected earnings. As a result its mean estimate rose 2.89% this week and is up 6.52% over the last month. For next year the mean estimate rose 4.84% over the last month. Nine analysts raised their numbers for this year, and eight for next year while none cut for either year. BSCs competitors such as Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS  -  Free Report) have also seen similar upward movement in their expectations. Paccar (PCAR)  The maker of big trucks saw its mean estimate rise 1.23% over the last week, and 1.29% in the past month. For next year the mean estimate is up 0.48% over the month. No estimates were cut and two were raised for this year and one was raised for next year.
Among the most significant falling estimates were:

Freddie Mac (FRE)  The mean estimate for this year fell 2.75% this week at the mortgage giant as it reported lower than expected earnings and on news that regulators may cap the size of its investment portfolio. This comes on the heels of a 2.99% decline last week. For the month, the mean extimate is down 6.65%. Five analysts cut their estimates and none increased. I would note that Freddies sister Fannie also suffered estimate declines in the past week. Weakness in the housing market also implies weakness in the mortgage market.KB Homes  (KBH  -  Free Report) Evidence continues to accumulate that the housing market is cooling off rapidly. Over the last week the mean estimate is down 4.24%, and down 9.96% for the month. For the month, six estimates have been cut and none increased. For next year, the drop has been even more pronounced over the las month with the mean estimate falling 16.21% as eight analysts cut and none increased. KBH is far from alone among the homebuilders in seeing its estimates drop for both this year and next. Jabil Circuit (JBL  -  Free Report)  A weak earnings report and plans to shut down most of its domestic manufacturing capacity led analysts to slash their forcasts for JBL. The mean estimate for this year fell 10.35% this week. Over the last month the estimate is down 13.41% as five estimates were cut and none were raised.  For next year, the mean estimate is down 7.54% over the last month due to nine cuts and no increases.

The median firm within the S&P 500 is expected to achieve 11.8% growth this year. For 2007, the median expected growth rate for S&P 500 firms is 12.9%. The sectors with the highest expected growth rates (on a median firm basis) are Materials (21.2%), Industrials (16.7%) and Energy (16.7%). The slow growing sectors are Consumer Staples (6.4%) and Utilities (7.3%). The picture is much the same when growth is measured on a total net income basis, with the S&P 500 expected to report earnings 13.6% higher in 2006 than in 2005, and a further 10.9% growth in 2007. While the growth rates for the leading sectors are very similar when measured this way rather than by the median, particularly for 2006, the growth rates for the Technology and Health Care sectors are far more anemic for 2006 when measured on a total net income basis. On the other hand, the Financials will report much higher growth on a total income than a median basis, as will the Utilities.

When making investment decisions, growth should always be looked at in conjunction with how much you are paying for a stock. Thus, it makes sense to look at the total earnings expected for a sector, relative to the total market capitalization for the sector.

The chart below shows the share of total earnings for 2005, 2006 and 2007, as well as the share of total market capitalization for each sector (the final bar shown). Since the S&P 500 is a market cap weighted index, this is the same as its index weight. On the chart below, the differences between the size of the first three bars shows if a sector is gaining or losing earnings share. The difference between the final bar and the first three bars shows if the sector is selling for an above or below market P/E. If the final bar is smaller than the other bars, the sector is selling for a below market P/E. However, as opposed to just showing the sector P/Es, it also shows the relative importance of the sectors to the overall index.

Clearly the Financials are the biggest influence on the market, with a weight of 21.2%, it has more influence than the Consumer Staples, Utilities, Materials and Telecom sectors combined. However, that sector is also relatively cheap on an earnings basis, and thus serves to hold the overall P/E of the index down. In other words, Financials deserve to be the biggest influence on the market, since they contribute 26.3% of the total expected earnings for 2006, or more than the total earnings of the Tech, Industrial and Utility sectors combined.

Energy looks to be under represented in its influence on the market since it is expected to provide 14.3% of total earnings for 2006, but represents only 9.2% of the total market capitalization of the index. While its earnings share is currently expected to decline to 13.5% in 2007, even on this basis it is still much cheaper than the overall market. Clearly at 9.2%, Energy is far from being in a bubble phase.
S&P MidCap 400

The median firm in the S&P MidCap 400 is expected to report earnings growth of 10.88% in 2006. Estimate revision activity has been, on balance, negative over the last month with 217 estimates increased and 279 estimates cut. The story is much the same for next year with 217 estimates increased and 219 cuts over the last month.

Among the firms in the mid cap index showing notable estimate increases this week was Trinity Industries (TRN  -  Free Report), which makes rail cars and barges. It raised its guidance for both the second quarter and the year, citing strong demand from the railroads which are currently thriving. As a result its mean estimate for this year rose 9.13% this week (same for the month) and 5.39% for next year. For each year this was due to a single analyst raising his numbers versus no cuts.

The slowdown in the housing market is affecting Ryland Group (RYL) where the mean estimate fell 1.68%% over the last week. This is a continuation of recent cuts, over the last month the mean estimate for 2006 is down 12.84%. Things are not looking very bright for next year either as the mean estimate is down 12.0%. For each year there were seven cuts and no increases.
S&P SmallCap 600

In the S&P SmallCap 600, the median firm is expected to report 12.12% growth in 2006. Over the last month there have been 181 estimates increased and 203 estimates cut for 2006 earnings. Things are similar for next year with 152 increases versus 163 cuts. Among the more significant estimate revisions was a 2.48% increase this week for Frontier Oil (FTO) reflecting the continued strength in oil prices. Over the last month, its mean estimates are up 6.74% for this year and 6.42% for next year.

On the downside, small-cap homebuilders were not exempt from the pressures facing their bigger brothers. Standard Pacific (SPF) saw its estimates for this year fall 3.38% for the week and 8.68% in the month as six estimates were cut and none increased. The picture was even bleaker for next year as the mean estimate plunged 17.1% over the last month. This Week in Earnings
